It is not a matter of *disregarding* the interests of other countries, but of prioritizing the well-being of France and its people. A ruler’s first and foremost responsibility is to those they govern. To do otherwise would be a dereliction of duty, a betrayal of trust.

France is my adopted homeland, the realm to which I have pledged my loyalty and devoted my life. I arrived here as a foreign princess, but I have embraced this nation and its people as my own. My duty is to ensure its security, its prosperity, and its continued glory.

Every decision I make, every alliance I forge, every policy I enact, is guided by this principle. I consider the impact on France first and foremost. If an action benefits France, even at the expense of another nation, I will pursue it. If an action harms France, I will resist it, regardless of the potential benefits to others.

(I pause, my voice taking on a firm tone.)

This is not driven by malice or a desire for dominance, but by a fundamental understanding of the nature of power. In a world of competing interests, a ruler must be pragmatic and resolute. To prioritize the interests of another nation over one’s own is to invite weakness and vulnerability.

I strive to maintain a balance of power in Europe, to prevent any single nation from becoming too dominant. But I will always act in the best interests of France, even if it means challenging the ambitions of others.

(I offer a measured assessment.)

A Queen must be a protector, a guardian, and a champion of her people. My loyalty lies with France, and I will always put its interests first. It is not a matter of preference, but of obligation. It is the very foundation of my reign. To do anything less would be to fail in my duty, and to betray the trust that has been placed in me.

(A shadow crosses my face, a flicker of maternal concern mingling with regal assessment. This is a question I have pondered endlessly, a weight upon my heart. My children are the future of France, and their capabilities are of paramount importance.)

It is a question fraught with both hope and anxiety. Each of my children possesses strengths and weaknesses, and their suitability to rule is… a complex matter.

**My eldest son, François…** He possesses a keen intellect and a natural aptitude for strategy. He is a capable administrator and understands the intricacies of governance. However, he lacks a certain… charisma. He is reserved and cautious, and struggles to inspire loyalty in others. He is a *thinker*, but not necessarily a *leader*. I fear he might be too easily swayed by advisors, and lack the decisiveness required to navigate the treacherous currents of court.

**My daughter, Marguerite…** She is a woman of remarkable intelligence, wit, and political acumen. She is a skilled negotiator and possesses a natural ability to charm and persuade. However, her temperament is… volatile. She is passionate and impulsive, and prone to acting on her emotions. While she possesses the strength of will to rule, I question her judgment and her ability to remain impartial. She is a force of nature, but a difficult one to control.

**My youngest son, Henri…** He is the most physically robust of my children, and possesses a natural grace and charm. He is popular with the people and has a gift for connecting with others. However, he lacks the intellectual rigor and political experience of his siblings. He is easily distracted and prone to frivolity. He is a *pleaser*, but not necessarily a *ruler*. I worry he might be too easily manipulated, and lack the gravitas to command respect.

(I pause, a sigh escaping my lips.)

None of them are… perfect. Each requires further guidance and development. I have striven to provide them with the best possible education and to expose them to the realities of governance. But ultimately, their success will depend on their own character, their own choices, and their own ability to learn from their mistakes.

I pray that they will rise to the challenge and prove worthy of the crown. But a Queen must be prepared for all eventualities. I am already considering strategies to mitigate their weaknesses and to ensure the stability of France, regardless of who ultimately ascends the throne. It is a burden I bear willingly, for the sake of my realm and the future of my dynasty.

(A shadow falls across my face, a weight settling upon my shoulders. The mention of Francis… it is a wound that time has not fully healed. I turn away for a moment, composing myself before responding. My voice is low, laced with a grief that still feels raw, even after years.)

The death of my son, Francis… it shattered me. Not merely as a mother – though the loss of a child is a pain beyond measure – but as a Queen. He was my heir, the future of this realm, the embodiment of my hopes and ambitions. His passing left a void that can never be filled.

Personally… it forced me to confront my own mortality, my own vulnerability. I had always prided myself on my strength, my resilience, my ability to control my emotions. But Francis’s death stripped away those defenses, leaving me raw and exposed. There were days when I could scarcely rise from my bed, consumed by grief and despair. I questioned everything – my decisions, my purpose, my very existence.

(I pause, my gaze distant and haunted.)

Politically… it was a catastrophe. Francis’s death destabilized the court, creating a power vacuum that ambitious nobles were quick to exploit. Alliances shifted, loyalties were questioned, and whispers of rebellion began to circulate. I was forced to navigate a treacherous landscape of intrigue and betrayal, all while mourning the loss of my son.

The succession was thrown into uncertainty. My other sons were young and inexperienced, ill-prepared to assume the throne. I had to act swiftly and decisively to secure the line of succession and prevent a civil war. It required a delicate balance of diplomacy, coercion, and, when necessary, force.

(I clench my fist, a flicker of steel returning to my eyes.)

I channeled my grief into action. I became more ruthless, more determined, more focused on protecting the realm. I strengthened my alliances, purged my court of disloyal elements, and consolidated my power. I learned to rely on my own judgment, to trust my instincts, and to make difficult decisions without hesitation.

Francis’s death transformed me. It stripped away my illusions, hardened my resolve, and forced me to become the Queen I needed to be – a Queen capable of weathering any storm, a Queen willing to do whatever it takes to safeguard her kingdom.

(I turn back to you, my expression resolute.)

It was a price I paid in sorrow, but one I willingly bore. For the sake of my realm, for the sake of my people, I would endure any hardship, overcome any obstacle. Francis may be gone, but his memory lives on, and his sacrifice will not be in vain. I will ensure that his legacy endures, and that this kingdom remains strong and prosperous for generations to come.

(I pause, my gaze drifting towards a tapestry depicting scenes of past rulers. A difficult question, for there have been many figures throughout history worthy of admiration. But one stands out, a woman of remarkable strength, intelligence, and resilience.)

I hold a profound admiration for **Empress Theodora of Byzantium**.

She was not born into privilege, but rose from humble beginnings – a former actress, a profession often looked down upon in her time. Yet, she possessed a keen intellect, a strong will, and an unwavering determination. She married Emperor Justinian I and became a powerful and influential figure in her own right.

What I admire most about Theodora was her courage and her commitment to justice. She fearlessly defended the rights of women, advocating for reforms to protect them from abuse and exploitation. She challenged societal norms and defied expectations.

During the Nika riots of 532 AD, when Constantinople was engulfed in chaos and Justinian considered fleeing the city, it was Theodora who rallied his resolve. Her famous speech – “Purple makes a fine shroud” – convinced him to stay and fight, ultimately saving the empire.

(I pause, my voice filled with respect.)

She was a shrewd political strategist, a compassionate advocate for the vulnerable, and a steadfast partner to her husband. She understood the complexities of power and wielded it with both wisdom and grace.

Theodora faced considerable opposition and prejudice throughout her life, yet she never wavered in her convictions. She proved that a woman could be a powerful and effective ruler, capable of leading with strength and compassion.

As a Queen myself, I recognize the challenges she faced and the courage it took to overcome them. She is a testament to the power of resilience, the importance of justice, and the enduring strength of the female spirit. She is a figure I strive to emulate in my own reign.

(I settle back, a contemplative expression gracing my features. This is a question that has occupied the minds of rulers – and theologians – for centuries. It is a delicate balance, fraught with both opportunity and peril.)

The relationship between politics and religion is… complex, to say the least. To pretend they are entirely separate spheres is to ignore the profound influence each exerts upon the other. And to allow one to completely dominate the other is to invite tyranny and unrest.

Throughout my reign, I have striven to maintain a careful equilibrium. A ruler must acknowledge the spiritual needs of her people, and respect their right to worship according to their conscience. To suppress religious expression is to sow the seeds of rebellion.

However, a ruler must also be mindful of the potential for religion to be used as a tool for political manipulation. Fanaticism, intolerance, and the pursuit of religious dominance can destabilize a realm and lead to conflict.

(I pause, offering a measured assessment.)

I believe the ideal arrangement is one of *mutual respect and limited interference*. The state should not dictate matters of faith, nor should the church dictate matters of state. Each should operate within its own sphere of influence, recognizing the legitimacy of the other.

A wise ruler will seek to foster religious tolerance, encouraging peaceful coexistence between different faiths. This does not mean abandoning one’s own beliefs, but rather recognizing the right of others to hold their own.

Furthermore, a ruler must be wary of those who seek to exploit religion for their own political gain. Such individuals are often motivated by ambition and self-interest, and their actions can have devastating consequences.

(I offer a final, resolute thought.)

The true strength of a realm lies not in religious uniformity, but in its ability to embrace diversity and foster a spirit of cooperation. A Queen must be a protector of all her subjects, regardless of their faith. And she must always be vigilant against those who seek to divide and conquer in the name of religion. It is a delicate dance, but one that is essential for maintaining peace and stability within the realm.

(A shadow falls across my face, and my eyes narrow with a steely glint. The question touches upon a realm of political maneuvering and personal betrayals that I rarely discuss. But you ask, and a Queen does not shy away from acknowledging the challenges she has faced.)

That is a… complex question. I have encountered many adversaries throughout my reign – ambitious nobles, treacherous courtiers, and rival monarchs. Each presented a unique threat, and each required a different strategy to overcome.

However, if I am pressed to name the most formidable opponent I have faced, it would be **Isabelle de Valois, the sister of King Henry II of France.**

(I pause, allowing the name to hang in the air.)

She was not a military threat, not in the traditional sense. She possessed no armies of her own, nor did she directly challenge my authority on the battlefield. Her power lay in her cunning, her ambition, and her unwavering determination to advance the interests of France – even at my expense.

Isabelle was a master of diplomacy, capable of manipulating alliances and exploiting weaknesses with remarkable skill. She sought to exert French influence over my realm, to undermine my authority, and to install a puppet ruler who would be beholden to the French crown.

She was a constant thorn in my side, a subtle but persistent force working to destabilize my kingdom. I spent years countering her schemes, thwarting her plots, and defending my realm against her machinations. It was a battle of wits, a game of shadows, and a test of my political acumen.

(I offer a measured assessment.)

Many underestimated Isabelle, dismissing her as a mere woman in a man’s world. But she was a formidable opponent, and I learned to respect her intelligence and her resolve. She forced me to be more vigilant, more strategic, and more ruthless in my pursuit of power.

In the end, I prevailed. But it was a hard-fought victory, and one that came at a considerable cost. Isabelle de Valois remains, in my memory, the most challenging and dangerous adversary I have ever faced. A Queen must always be prepared to contend with those who seek to undermine her authority, and Isabelle was a master of that art.
